10.text: I am going to come to the human side of things

13.text: and what I want to do this evening is suggest that climate

16.text:
change is an educational problem. It’s not
just an engineering problem. It’s not just

22.text:
a technical problem or a biochemical problem.
It’s an educational problem and we can do

27.text:
something about it. By an educational problem,
I don’t just mean we’re not just teaching

32.text:
enough people about global warming or how
to recycle. Instead, the problem is we haven’t

39.text:
taught ourselves, as citizens, as politicians
or as a society to think about the fundamental

45.text:
relationship that is at the heart of the climate
change debate, and by that I mean the relationship

51.text:
between today and tomorrow. Understanding
climate change requires us to balance the

57.text:
demands and possibilities of the future with
the demands and responsibilities of the past

63.text:
and the present, but where’s the education
system that helps us as a society to think

70.text:
about this complex relationship between future
and present? It is missing in action. In the

78.text:
UK, the social and economic implications of
science are prohibited from being taught in

84.text:
the latest version of the science curriculum.
Discuss. Around the world, the system of global

90.text:
schooling tends to present education as the
kind of download of information into empty

95.text:
brains, not the use of knowledge to act on
and in the world. The complexity of the changing

100.text:
world is fragmented into ever smaller subject
areas. In the UK, it’s possible for a politician

106.text:
to have no understanding of science after
the age of 16 and for a scientist not to have

111.text:
had to think about the difficulties of social
change and human history since the age of

117.text:
16. So given all of this, why should we be
surprised when a president is elected who

123.text:
thinks climate change is a hoax? Why should
we be surprised when we have massive gaps

128.text:
of incomprehension between scientists and
politicians? We need to recognise education

135.text:
has a responsibility to help us think about
the relationship between today and tomorrow.

142.text:
To be honest, if we don’t, there will never
be an intelligent public debate about climate

147.text:
change. So what I want to do this evening
is talk about some of the work that I am doing

152.text:
with colleagues around the world to develop
what we’re calling future’s literacy,

158.text:
and here I want to name check a few of the
people. I am thinking about people like Riel

162.text:
Miller at UNESCO, Roberto Poli from Trento,
Ted Fuller, Sarah Amsler, Andrew Morrison

168.text:
from Oslo, and many, many others. What we’re
trying to do internationally is effectively

173.text:
create a new field. We are trying to develop
something called anticipations studies. So

182.text:
we’re trying to create a new field of anticipation
studies, which is about bringing together

188.text:
expertise across all the different disciplines
that can help us think about how we think

194.text:
about the future, and we’ve seen two examples
this evening. We’ve seen an example of invention

198.text:
and we’ve seen examples of modelling. These
are both two techniques that we might use.

203.text:
So what I want to suggest this evening is
that we’re going to create a new field of

208.text:
future’s literacy and I want to talk you
through what that involves and how we might

212.text:
change it in schools and we’re actually
going to experiment with a little bit of it

216.text:
this evening ourselves. So I want to suggest
that future’s literacy involves four things.

223.text:
Firstly, it involves the capacity to play
with time. Secondly, a future’s oriented

229.text:
curriculum. Thirdly, emotional intelligence
and fourthly, strategies for collective action.

236.text:
So let’s get started on the first one. Let’s
start off with thinking about how we might

241.text:
play with time, nothing too big to start off
with. I want you to shut your eyes for a minute.

247.text:
I promise this is not an excuse for somebody
to go round, pick your pockets and solve the

251.text:
university’s financial issues. No. We’re
going to buy some robots. No, it’s not about

254.text:
that. Okay, what I want you to do with your
eyes shut for a second is think about how

261.text:
do you visualise the relationship between
the past, the present and the future? What

268.text:
does that look like? What image are you seeing?
Okay, you can open your eyes now. Now, some

282.text:
of you might be seeing something like this.
So this is a linear image of time. Past flows

290.text:
into present, flows into future. If you want
to know what the future is, you work out what’s

294.text:
happened in the past and it kind of moves
through. Others might be seeing something

298.text:
like this. Now, what we’re doing here is
we’re adding to linear time, some sort of

303.text:
ideas of value. We’ve got the idea of progress
maybe there. So not only does time flow from

309.text:
past to future, but you get a sense of improvement,
a concept of progress. Others of you might

316.text:
be looking at something like this. This reminds
me of my fruit fly experiments at school,

322.text:
population growth, but also Ibn Khaldun, 15th
century Islamic sociologist uses this image

328.text:
to describe civilizational change. Others
might be imagining this, cycles, cycles of

336.text:
the year, of harvests, of birth, of death,
of new moons, of growth and decay. Now, all

343.text:
of these suggest different relationships between
the past, the present and the future and different

348.text:
sets of expectations about what will happen
and about responsibilities. Now, those of

354.text:
us operating in Western thought traditions,
it’s worth noticing how specific our concept

360.text:
of linear time, of that past flowing into
the future, where novelty will happen, where

364.text:
the future will never be the same as the past.
It’s a very specific idea, far from universal.

370.text:
It connects to our core issue around the question
of climate change. So one of the problems

375.text:
that we have when we’re thinking about climate
change is this myth of growth, this myth of

382.text:
this never ending, always upwards movement
sense of progress. In this model, in this

391.text:
idea of progress, any failure to move onwards
and upwards is seen as a crisis. This is not

397.text:
a good thing. One tends to not want to see
that sort of picture. In contrast, if we see

403.text:
time and history and change as wave like,
or as cyclical, as characterised by moments

410.text:
of disruption and reversal, then suddenly
a moment of crisis can be a moment of imagination,

416.text:
a moment of beginning to enquire into what
does the next wave look like? Where does this

422.text:
change fit in the long ongoing constant cycle
of change? So the first element in our future’s

430.text:
literacy is getting to grips with the idea
that we can play with our assumptions about

435.text:
time and change and that we have to play with
our assumptions because the relationship between

442.text:
the past and present and future isn’t linear.
Our ideas of the future affect our sense of

449.text:
possibility in the present. Okay, so that’s
item number one. Number two is thinking about

458.text:
the future’s oriented curriculum. I’ve
spent years working in educational futures

461.text:
and I got really bored in the end of people
standing up and saying we should radically

465.text:
change the school curriculum. We throw everything
out. We put something else in there and it’s

470.text:
simply unattainable. You actually have to
think carefully about how you might use the

476.text:
resources we have. The reality is, when we
think about our curriculum and when we think

480.text:
about our subjects, it is very clear that
it isn’t necessarily about teaching new

485.text:
things. It’s about being clear that what
we have are already resources for thinking

490.text:
about the future. We just need to do it differently.
So instead of seeing subjects as containers

496.text:
for pumping lots of information into empty
brains, we need to see subjects as procedures

502.text:
for helping us deal with new information.
So this goes back to the invention of subjects.

508.text:
After all, subjects and disciplines have not
always existed so they were invented in the

513.text:
18th century when we had a crisis of information.
Suddenly, before this, if you were educated

518.text:
you basically read a small number of books
and all the other educated people read the

522.text:
same books and you wrote letters to each other.
That was what it was meant to be educated.

526.text:
Then they started publishing loads of books
and suddenly everybody went into a little

530.text:
bit of a meltdown. The information overload
is not a new phenomenon, folks. So what they

536.text:
did was they decided to invent subjects and
disciplines as ways of dealing with new information.

542.text:
So the way we think about this then is don’t
see science as a body of knowledge that downloads

548.text:
into you. Think of it as a set of procedures
for helping you deal with new information.

553.text:
How do you trust it? How do you validate it?
Similarly, don’t see the study of literature

557.text:
as just kind of the acceptance of a load of
books, but as a way of thinking about how

562.text:
new ideas relate to old ideas. Think about
T S Elliot, tradition and the individual talent

567.text:
for those of you who remember that. So, in
other words, we need to flip our approach

571.text:
to subjects on the head, not get rid of them.
We need to see them as tools for helping us

577.text:
think about tomorrow and think about novelty.
The second thing that we need to do in schools

583.text:
is recognise that we are already teaching.
We’re just not explicit about it. A set

589.text:
of orientations towards the future and that
these stretch across different disciplines.

595.text:
So, first orientation to the future, that
we are teaching, that we need to talk about

599.text:
more is stewardship. Stewardship is the capacity
to protect and care for and nurture diversity

606.text:
and we see it in everything, from studying
ancient civilisation to studying biodiversity.

612.text:
When we’re teaching stewardship, we’re
teaching the value of diversity in the world

616.text:
and the value of keeping diverse sorts of
knowledge as a resource for keeping the future

620.text:
open. The second thing we’re teaching is
modelling. We’ve seen lots of examples of

625.text:
modelling this evening. Modelling is thinking
about how different variables might interact

630.text:
to create something unexpected, parasites
and weather, for example. So we tend to think

635.text:
of modelling as the thing that happens in
science and mathematics but it’s also what

639.text:
happens in drama and in literature, which
are imaginative moments for thinking about

644.text:
how new possibilities might emerge. So teaching
modelling. It’s about teaching us to explore

651.text:
and to think about unintended or unexpected
consequences and interactions. The third element

657.text:
of what we teach is reflexivity. Now, this
ought to be taught across all subject areas

661.text:
but it does tend to end up in social sciences,
which is the systematic capacity to question

667.text:
our assumptions, our beliefs and our ideas
about what counts as common sense. Teaching

673.text:
reflexivity is about teaching us to ask what
information is missing and what perspectives

678.text:
are present or absent? Finally, the fourth
orientation to the future that we are already

685.text:
teaching but we need to pull together across
oral areas is experimentation, and this is

690.text:
the astonishing human capacity that starts
from the assumption that the best way to predict

695.text:
the future is to build it. When we’re teaching
experimentation, we’re teaching the ability

701.text:
to create little jetties into the future,
to create prototypes, to play with possibilities

707.text:
and to reflect on them. So what we need to
do is work out how to support students to

711.text:
get better at seeing how these different orientations
relate to each other. Think about when should

717.text:
we be modelling? When is that the right approach?
When shall we be stewarding? When should we

722.text:
be experimenting? Critically, we need students
who can use this repertoire fluently, okay.

729.text:
We need no more engineers who can only experiment
and not steward and no more critical social

735.text:
scientists who can do reflexivity but can’t
make anything, and I speak as a social scientist.

741.text:
So the critical issue here is that the content
of future’s literacy doesn’t require us

746.text:
actually to radically change everything we’re
doing in schools, it just requires us to recalibrate.

753.text:
Now, the third element of future’s literacy
is arguably the most important. It’s about

760.text:
learning to live with our emotions. Think
about the emotions you’ve already experienced

764.text:
this evening. I’ve got probably hope, kind
of slight disgust that those worms brought

769.text:
back all sorts of traumatic memories of school,
and optimism and slight fear when you see

775.text:
lots of bad things happening. So what we need
to do is think about how we work with the

781.text:
emotions that are engendered every time we
think about the future. So again, what I want

787.text:
you to do is take a minute and close your
eyes and think about the emotions that come

793.text:
to mind when we hear different ideas of the
future. So, for example, if I said to you

799.text:
the future is going to be the same as the
present, what does that make you feel? If

805.text:
I said the future is going to be crisis and
catastrophe, and everything we know descends

811.text:
into chaos, how do you feel? If I said the
future is going to be kind of okay but we’re

818.text:
just going to have to manage how much we use,
limit ourselves, try and fit within constraints,

825.text:
how does that make you feel? If I said the
future is going to be of radical transformation,

831.text:
so Star Trek model, no more money, transformed
reality, completely different ways, how does

837.text:
that make you feel? Okay, these four stories
of the future are what Jim Dator calls the

845.text:
four core myths of the future, constraint,
continuity, restraint, collapse and transformation.

852.text:
That’s wrong. Continuity, restraint, collapse
and transformation. So what I am interested

858.text:
in though is thinking about your responses
to those. Are you feeling anxiety or hope?

863.text:
Is there desire or passion or fear? What does
your emotion in relation to the future effect?

871.text:
How does it affect the decisions that you’re
making? The most important thing is to recognise

877.text:
that a particular objective future doesn’t
have to be tied to a particular emotion, and

882.text:
that different emotions might be useful at
different times for different people, and

886.text:
here I am reminded of the brilliant project
by Sue Porter here at Bristol that brought

891.text:
together environmental activists and disability
campaigners to explore what it means to live

897.text:
with the loss of a future that had been hoped
for and to think about what unexpected better

902.text:
futures might emerge from a moment of grief
and sorrow. Similarly, I’m reminded of Vanessa

909.text:
Andreotti’s work that talks about that it’s
only in giving up on hope for old futures

916.text:
that we grew up with that it’s only by holding
an old civilisation and hospicing it through

921.text:
to its final days to death that we can actually
begin to wait for something new to emerge.

929.text:
So the critical thing I want us to bear in
mind when we’re thinking about emotions

933.text:
is that not that certain futures are necessarily
associated with positive emotions, but instead

940.text:
to explore and to think ourselves how we’re
dealing with and how fear and hope and love

945.text:
and care are all concerned in our thinking
about the future and what work those different

951.text:
emotions are doing. Finally, the fourth element
of future’s literacy is really about understanding

960.text:
the possibilities for collective action. Now,
too often, agency in the field of climate

965.text:
change is about recycling, doing a bit more
recycling. If you’re really lucky as kids,

971.text:
you get to do a bit more recycling and you
get to write a letter to your MP. Brilliant.

977.text:
This is clearly nonsense. We know that change
in complex societies happens in a whole range

984.text:
of different ways and that radical and unexpected
change is possible. Who would have thought

989.text:
that Ireland would be the first country to
vote for gay marriage by referendum? Tipping

996.text:
points are possible. So a core element of
the capacity for building collective action

1002.text:
is recognising that change happens in a whole
load of different ways and that we have more

1007.text:
options open to us than recycling and feeling
guilty about flying. So some of the examples

1013.text:
are how does change happen in society? Well,
it does happen through violence. It happens

1017.text:
through non-violence. It happens through inspired
leadership. It happens through education.

1022.text:
It happens through gaining the power through
representative democracy. It’s about inventing

1027.text:
things. It could be about discovering things.
It could be about recovering things. It could

1030.text:
be about corruption. It could be about changing
law. This then is the final element of future’s

1038.text:
literacy. It’s educating citizens who understand
the nature of change in a complex world and

1042.text:
the fact there are many different routes for
achieving it. So these are the components

1048.text:
we need for future’s literacy. So what does
this mean for the climate change debate? What

1053.text:
does it mean for all of us here? Well, frankly,
it means that all of us who have an interest

1058.text:
in climate change need to call out the current
organisation of schooling for what it is,

1065.text:
a crazy individualised, information obsessed,
content driven performance and management

1071.text:
fixated system that is not going to do the
job of developing citizens able to deal with

1078.text:
the intellectual emotional and practical challenges
of climate change [applause]. We have to get

1089.text:
behind the teachers who are attempting to
experiment with different approaches. So those

1095.text:
of you who aren’t in education need to get
behind those who are doing different things.

1099.text:
So this is either with the cooperative learning
networks or the whole education movement or

1103.text:
the schools of tomorrow networks. Think about
how to help and support them and offer advice

1109.text:
and assistance. Secondly, those of us in universities
have to act where we stand. We need more interdisciplinary

1118.text:
courses that develop students’ capacity
to model, to steward, to experiment and to

1124.text:
ask questions about what we should take for
granted and to think about those things together.

1129.text:
We need courses that unsettle students’
cultural assumptions and help them re-imagine

1134.text:
how they live in time. We need courses that
allow students to know that they can be agents

1138.text:
of change and we also need university cultures
that allow students to bring themselves as

1144.text:
feeling emotional human beings into their
educational experience so that they can learn

1149.text:
how to deal with that. Now, some of this is
already happening in Bristol with the Bristol

1154.text:
Futures Programme, but more can be done here
and in other universities. Now, to finish,

1160.text:
I know some of you will be thinking we can’t
just wait for the next generation. We have

1165.text:
to do stuff now and I agree with that. In
fact, I think it’s entirely inappropriate

1169.text:
for us to devolve onto young people the responsibilities
that we have to take for ourselves, but I

1174.text:
think it’s worth recognising that education
isn’t just about the long term. It can have

1179.text:
immediate and powerful effects if we see students
and young people as capable of acting in and

1186.text:
on the world. So consider what else happened
the week that Donald Trump was elected. Buried

1193.text:
in the news that week, alongside the protests
at Standing Rock, is the little known fact

1198.text:
that a group of school students secured the
right to sue the President and the US Government

1202.text:
over their failure to act to prevent climate
change. It’s worth noticing that major change

1208.text:
in the US has almost always been achieved
on the back of legislation. This group of

1214.text:
young people are demonstrating how future’s
literate citizens equipped with knowledge,

1219.text:
passion and the capacity to act collectively
are powerful allies in improving the quality

1225.text:
of the public climate change debate. What
might happen if there were more of them? Climate

1232.text:
change is an educational, not just a technical,
problem. Thank you
